edge.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the part of an object that is furthest from its centre
edge.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Put the eggs in the centre of the dish, with the vegetables and herbs around the edge.
He stood at the water’s edge staring across the lake.
A leaf was on the ground, curling up at the edges.
the right hand edge of the page
Jennifer walked to the edge of the wood.
Billy sat on the edge of the bed.
edge.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: the thin sharp part of a blade or tool that cuts
edge.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: a knife with a sharp edge
edge.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: something that gives you an advantage over others
edge.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Companies are employing more research teams to get an edge.
The next version of the software will have the edge over its competitors.
edge.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a quality in someone’s voice that makes it sound slightly angry or impatient
edge.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: There was an edge of hostility in Jack’s voice.
Desperation lent an edge to her voice.
edge.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: an area beside a very steep slope
edge.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: She walked almost to the edge of the cliff.
edge.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: a special quality of excitement or danger
edge.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: The school’s campaign has been given an extra edge by being filmed for television.
edge.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: the part of an object that is furthest from its centre
edge.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: I gripped the top edge of the door and pulled myself up.
The lower edge of the window frame was starting to rot.
I banged my elbow on the front edge of the desk.
He painted carefully around the inner edge of each door.
The airport is located on the outer edge of town.
There’s a ridge of hills on the northern edge of the county.
The castle stands on the edge of the sea.
We sat down at the water’s edge.
edge.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 3: something that gives you an advantage over others
edge.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: We believe our products have the edge over the competition.
A well trained workforce is a key factor in gaining a competitive edge over our rivals.
I hope my qualifications and experience will give me the edge.
He’s had a lot of injuries and lost a lot of his competitive edge.
Running on the inside lane will give him a slight edge.
Being tall gives you a distinct edge in some sports.
He believes investment in new technology is the only way for the company to maintain its competitive edge.
edge.translation[0].note_box[2].sections: edge
the part of something that is furthest from its centre or nearest the place where it ends
He got up quickly, knocking his plate off the edge of the table.
the outer edge of the village
side
the part of something that is near its left or right edge
On the left side of the garden there was an old stone wall.
They parked by the side of the road.
rim
the edge of something circular, especially the top of a cup or glass, or the outside edge of a pair of glasses
a white cup with a gold rim
She was looking at me over the rim of her spectacles.
margin
the empty space at the side of a page that has writing on it
My teacher had marked my essay and made some comments in the margin.
Leave wide margins on both sides of the page.
hem
the edge of a piece of cloth that is turned under and stitched down, especially the lower edge of a skirt, trousers etc
If you want the dress a bit shorter, I can easily turn up the hem.
kerb
the edge of the pavement (=raised path)
A big black car was parked at the kerb.
outskirts
the areas of a city that are furthest away from the centre
The new station was built on the outskirts of the city.
perimeter
the outside edge around an enclosed area of land such as a military camp or a prison
Security guards patrol the perimeter night and day.
edge.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to move gradually with several small movements, or to make something do this
edge.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Tim was edging away from the crowd.
She edged closer to get a better look.
He edged her towards the door.
Christine edged her way round the back of the house.
edge your way into/round/through etc something
edge.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to put something on the edge or border of something
edge.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The city square was edged by trees.
The tablecloth is edged with lace.
edge.translation[1].definitions[1].note_: Edge is usually passive in this meaning
edge.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to change gradually, especially so as to get better or worse
edge.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The paper has edged ahead of  (=been more successful than) its rivals.
edge.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: to cut the edges of an area of grass so that they are tidy and straight
edge.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: if a person, company, or country has an edge over others, they are more successful, profitable etc because they have an advantage that the others do not have
edge.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: They have a slight edge over their competitors.
It has lower overheads than many similar companies, giving it an important competitive edge.
edge.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to increase by a small amount
edge.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Consumer prices edged up 0.2% last month.
Hong Kong edged ahead after a day of sharp swings.
edge.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: to decrease by a small amount
edge.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: Sales of cars, trucks and buses in Japan edged down 0.9% in January.
The index, which had climbed to 106.6 in late July, edged back to 100.4.
